While their senior year may not look as they thought it would and there are many unknowns about the next few weeks, we want our seniors to know two things.

1. Seniors, you are special.
You've successfully completed 13 years of school, even if the last year was quite different than others. You've worked hard, you've accomplished many things, and we (all Roane County citizens) are extremely proud of you.

2. Seniors, you are supported.
Every teacher, principal, community member, and school peer that you have been in contact with over the years has been in your life for a reason...either to teach you a good lesson or a lesson from which you have learned how to handle a situation differently than someone else. As you move forward after high school, you have a community of cheerleaders wishing you the best of luck and watching to see what you do.

Let’s recognize and support our seniors as they adjust, adapt, and thrive! The images and words have been shared straight from our students. Their words are their own, and the world is now theirs!

While their senior year may not look as they thought it would and there are many unknowns about the next few weeks, we want our seniors to know two things.

1. Seniors, you are special.
You've successfully completed 13 years of school, even if the last year was quite different than others. You've worked hard, you've accomplished many things, and we (all Roane County citizens) are extremely proud of you.

2. Seniors, you are supported.
Every teacher, principal, community member, and school peer that you have been in contact with over the years has been in your life for a reason...either to teach you a good lesson or a lesson from which you have learned how to handle a situation differently than someone else. As you move forward after high school, you have a community of cheerleaders wishing you the best of luck and watching to see what you do.

Let’s recognize and support our seniors as they adjust, adapt, and thrive! The images and words have been shared straight from our students. Their words are their own, and the world is now theirs!

At Governor Lee’s recommendation for Tennessee schools, Roane County Schools (TN) will be physically closed the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year due to COVID-19. Please wait for additional information to become available; we will share details and specifics as soon as possible.

1. We are working on a way to register Pre-K and Kindergarten students. We will share information as it becomes available.

2. Questions about graduation, prom, diplomas, and other senior-related events will be answered once all details are worked out and decisions are made.

3. Individual schools will be sharing information specific to that school; please follow your individual school’s Facebook page.

4. Students should still continue to participate in learning opportunities at home, either what’s been provided on paper, in an online format, or activities chosen by parents/guardians. Reading, cooking, writing, household chores, physical activity, puzzles, and board games are great ways to continue learning at home.

We cannot thank our School Nutrition team enough for what they are doing to feed our students during the extended closure. They are true superheroes on a mission to keep our students and their siblings fed. Across the district, students are receiving much needed food, and while it’s not an easy task, they understand its importance and do the work with a smile.

Each child in Roane County 18 years or younger can receive free breakfast and lunch from one of our pickup locations. Visit www.roaneschools.com for more information on our RCS Feeding Plan.

Remember next week begins a new schedule of Tuesday and Thursday pickup/delivery. Students will receive two breakfasts and two lunches on Tuesday and three breakfasts and three lunches on Thursday. Students are still getting 5 days worth of meals.

Thank you again to everyone making our RCS Feeding Plan possible!

Email Scam Alert

Please be aware of an email scam that is being reported in our district (and others).

Folks with too much time on their hands are creating email addresses that resemble those of our district staff or use their name in the signature. The email subject line is “Need Your Help”, “Please Help”, “Urgent Matter”, or something similar. Once you engage the sender, they ask you to send or buy gift cards, money transfer, etc.

As a district, we have no control over this, as anyone can create an email address with anyone’s name. The best line of defense is to report the spam Gmail account and be vigilant of sender’s addresses. Please keep in mind that our staff email addresses end in @roaneschools.com. Report any issues using the following link:
https://support.google.com/mail/contact/abuse

Eighth grade science classes had a visitor from Y-12 today.

Heather is a graduate of Harriman High School, as well as an alum of HMS. She comes every year to visit her hometown schools and talk with students about careers in engineering and what they should consider if they think they would like to enter the field.

She also challenged the students to build the tallest possible structure they could, using just 15 index cards, a handful of paper clips, and a short length of scotch tape!

The tallest structure of the day reached 30.5 inches!
